subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wp|lang=ja|ニワトリ}} {{wp|Chicken}}
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|にわとり}} {{IPAfont|⟨nipa tu to2ri⟩}} → *{{IPAchar|/nipatːəri/}} → {{IPAchar|/nifatori/}} → {{IPAchar|/niwatori/}} Originally derived from the {{m|ja|枕詞|tr=makura kotoba||pillow word|pos=an [[epithet]] as a poetic device}} compound phrase {{m|ja|庭つ鳥|tr=niwa tsu tori}}, {{compound|ja|sort=にわとり|庭|tr1=niwa|t1=[[garden]]|つ|tr2=tsu|pos2={{inh|ja|ojp|-}} possessive particle|鳥|tr3=tori|t3=[[bird]]}}, used in {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=にわとり}} poetry as an allusive introduction to ''kake'', the older word for “chicken” (see below). The medial ''tsu'' disappeared over time, yielding modern Japanese ''niwatori''.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}

subSections.title: Noun
Proverbs
subSections.text: * {{ja-r|鶏を割くに焉んぞ牛刀を用いん|にわとり を さく に いずくん ぞ ぎゅうとう を もち.いん|why [[chop]] a chicken with a [[beef]] [[cleaver]]? → don't [[exaggerate]]}}

subSections.title: Etymology 2
Noun
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|くたかけ}}
From {{inh|ja|ojp|-}}.

Compound of {{compound|ja|sort=くたかけ|くた|tr1=kuta|pos1=root for numerous verbs, implying "[[low-grade]], [[rotten]], [[stinky]]"|かけ|tr2=kake|t2=[[chicken]]|pos2=see above}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

Formerly a [[derogatory]] term for a chicken. Over time, the derogatory sense was lost, and the term instead took on an [[old-fashioned]] or [[archaic]] sense.

subSections.title: Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text: Occasionally seen with the reading {{lang|ja|くだかけ}} (''kudakake'').<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

subSections.title: Derived terms
subSections.text:
* {{ja-r|鶏の空%音|とり の そら%ね|[[cock]]'s [[false]] [[cry]]}}
* {{ja-r|鶏冠|とさか|[[cockscomb]]}}
